questions.question: At 55 mph on dry pavement with good brakes, the total stopping distance for a heavy vehicle is approximately:
questions.explanation: At 55 mph, your vehicle will travel a minimum of 419 feet to come to a complete stop.

questions.question: When driving, you should look at least how far ahead?
questions.explanation: Look at least 12 to 15 seconds ahead. That means looking ahead the distance you will travel in 12 to 15 seconds.

questions.question: How far ahead does 12 to 15 seconds represent at lower speeds?
questions.explanation: At lower speeds, looking 12 to 15 seconds ahead is about one block.

questions.question: If you double your speed from 20 to 40 mph, the impact in a crash will be:
questions.explanation: When you double your speed from 20 to 40 mph, the impact is 4 times greater.

questions.question: Hydroplaning can occur at speeds as low as:
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning can occur at speeds as low as 30 mph if there is a lot of water.

questions.question: On a two-lane road, how far from the vehicle should you place the rearmost warning device when stopped?
questions.explanation: On a two-lane road, place warning devices 10 feet, 100 feet, and 200 feet toward approaching traffic.

questions.question: During your trip, how often should you check your cargo?
choices: Only if you hear something shift
questions.explanation: Check cargo within the first 50 miles after beginning a trip and every 150 miles or every three hours thereafter.

questions.question: At 55 mph, perception distance (the distance traveled while recognizing a hazard) is approximately:
questions.explanation: Perception Distance is about 1.5 seconds. At 55 mph this accounts for 142 feet.

questions.question: At 55 mph, reaction distance (the distance traveled while moving your foot to the brake) is approximately:
questions.explanation: Reaction Distance is the distance traveled during reaction time (3/4 to 1 second). At 55 mph this accounts for 61 feet.

questions.question: What is the proper following distance rule for vehicles under 40 mph?
choices: 1 second for every 10 feet of vehicle length
questions.explanation: Allow at least one second for each 10 feet of vehicle length at speeds below 40 mph.

questions.question: At speeds over 40 mph, what additional following distance should you add?
questions.explanation: At speeds over 40 mph, you should add 1 second to your following distance.

questions.question: When should you downshift for a curve?
questions.explanation: You should slow down before entering a curve. Downshift before entering the curve - never while in it.

questions.question: What is the best way to check that your service brakes are working properly?
choices: Wait for the low air warning
Apply firm pressure while moving slowly and note if vehicle pulls to one side
questions.explanation: Move the vehicle forward slowly and apply the brakes firmly. Note any vehicle pulling to one side, unusual feel, or delayed stopping action.

questions.question: When testing hydraulic brakes, you should hold the brake pedal down for how long to check for leaks?
questions.explanation: With the engine running, apply firm pressure to the brake pedal for 5 seconds. The pedal should not move.

questions.question: If you triple your speed from 20 to 60 mph, how much greater is the impact and braking distance?
questions.explanation: Triple the speed from 20 to 60 mph and the impact and braking distance is 9 times greater.

questions.question: What is the minimum tread depth for front tires?
questions.explanation: Front tires must have tread depth of at least 4/32 inch.

questions.question: What is the minimum tread depth for other tires?
questions.explanation: Other tires must have tread depth of at least 2/32 inch.

questions.question: When backing a vehicle, you should:
choices: Back quickly to get it over with
Back toward the driver's side whenever possible
Always use the passenger side for better visibility
questions.explanation: Back to the driver's side so that you can see better. Backing toward the right side is very dangerous because you can't see as well.

questions.question: Why should you avoid backing toward the passenger side?
choices: It's easier to back toward the driver's side
questions.explanation: Backing toward the right (passenger) side is very dangerous because you can't see as well.

questions.question: What is the most common cause of serious vehicle fires?
questions.explanation: The most common cause of vehicle fires is fuel leaking around the engine.

questions.question: If you are driving in fog, you should use:
questions.explanation: In fog, use low beams. High beams reflect off the fog and reduce visibility.

questions.question: When driving in slippery conditions, how much more following distance should you allow?
questions.explanation: When roads are slippery, you need more distance to stop, so slow down and increase following distance.

questions.question: What is the proper way to use engine braking on a long downgrade?
choices: Stay in high gear and use the brakes constantly
Use a low gear before starting down and apply brakes only to prevent speeding
Apply brakes at the top and coast down
Alternate between high and low gear
questions.explanation: The use of brakes on a long and/or steep downgrade is only a supplement to the braking effect of the engine.

questions.question: What is 'brake fade'?
choices: Brakes losing effectiveness due to overheating
questions.explanation: Brake fade is caused by excessive heat from using brakes too much without relying on engine braking, causing chemical changes in brake linings and drum expansion.

questions.question: You should inspect your tires every:
questions.explanation: Check tires every 100 miles or every 2 hours.

questions.question: What class CDL is required for any combination of vehicles with a GCWR of 26,001 pounds or more (if towed vehicle is over 10,000 pounds)?
questions.explanation: Class A CDL is required for any combination of vehicles with a GCWR of 26,001 pounds or more, provided the GVWR of the vehicle being towed is in excess of 10,000 pounds.

questions.question: What class CDL is required for any single vehicle with a GVWR of 26,001 pounds or more?
questions.explanation: Class B CDL is required for any single vehicle with a GVWR of 26,001 pounds or more.

questions.question: To pass the CDL knowledge test, you must answer what percentage of questions correctly?
questions.explanation: For each test, 80 percent of the questions must be answered correctly to pass.

questions.question: How long must you hold a CDL instruction permit before taking the skills test?
questions.explanation: The permit must be held for 14 days prior to a skills test being administered.

questions.question: What BAC level will result in being put out of service for 24 hours when driving a commercial vehicle?
questions.explanation: If a driver tests from .01% BAC to .039% BAC, that driver shall be put out of service for 24 hours.

questions.question: What BAC level results in disqualification from commercial driving for one year (first offense)?
questions.explanation: Drivers testing at .04% BAC or higher will be disqualified for one year.

questions.question: A second conviction for DUI while driving a commercial motor vehicle results in:
questions.explanation: A second conviction of driving a commercial motor vehicle under the influence of alcohol or other drugs results in lifetime disqualification.

questions.question: How many serious traffic violations in three years results in a 60-day disqualification?
questions.explanation: Two serious moving violations in three years results in 60 days disqualification.

questions.question: How many serious traffic violations in three years results in a 120-day disqualification?
questions.explanation: Three serious moving violations in three years results in 120 days disqualification.

questions.question: Which is considered a 'serious violation'?
choices: Speeding 15 mph or more over the limit
questions.explanation: A serious violation includes speeding 15 mph or more, improper lane usage/changes, following too closely, reckless driving.

questions.question: When should you use your horn?
choices: To express frustration at other drivers
To let other drivers know you're there when necessary
Frequently to keep other drivers alert
questions.explanation: Use your horn to let others know you're there when needed, but avoid using it unnecessarily.

questions.question: What is the minimum number of tie-downs required for any flatbed load?
questions.explanation: There should be at least one tie-down for each 10 feet of cargo, with a minimum of two tie-downs.

questions.question: What is the minimum number of tie-downs for a 20-foot load?
questions.explanation: A 20-foot load requires a minimum of two tie-downs (one for each 10 feet).

questions.question: Cargo should be checked within the first how many miles of starting a trip?
questions.explanation: Check cargo within the first 50 miles after beginning a trip.

questions.question: What is the main reason for covering cargo on an open bed?
choices: To make the load look nicer
To protect the cargo and prevent it from falling
It's not necessary to cover cargo
questions.explanation: You should cover cargo to protect the cargo from weather and to prevent it from falling or blowing off.

questions.question: What should you do before transporting a sealed load?
choices: Check that you do not exceed weight limits
questions.explanation: Before transporting a sealed load, check that you don't exceed weight limits.

questions.question: How much weight can a cargo securement system be required to withstand?
questions.explanation: The securement system must be able to withstand 1.5 times the weight of the cargo.

questions.question: The most important reason for doing a vehicle inspection is:
questions.explanation: The most important reason for a vehicle inspection is safety - to find problems before they cause a crash or breakdown.

questions.question: What are three things you check during a pre-trip inspection of the engine compartment?
choices: Oil level, coolant level, power steering fluid
Tire pressure, tire tread, wheel nuts
questions.explanation: In the engine compartment, check oil level, coolant level, and power steering fluid among other things.

questions.question: What lights must you check during a vehicle inspection?
choices: Headlights and all other lights and reflectors
questions.explanation: Check headlights, tail lights, brake lights, turn signals, clearance lights, and all reflectors.

questions.question: When is it acceptable to exceed the speed limit?
questions.explanation: Never exceed the speed limit. Obey speed limits - they are set for ideal conditions.

questions.question: What color are the parking brake controls on newer vehicles with air brakes?
questions.explanation: In newer vehicles with air brakes, the parking brakes are controlled using a diamond-shaped, yellow, push-pull control knob.

questions.question: When must you use your headlights?
choices: 30 minutes before sunset to 30 minutes after sunrise, and any time visibility is reduced
questions.explanation: Headlights are required from a half hour after sunset to a half hour before sunrise, or any time you can't see clearly.

questions.question: What does GCWR stand for?
questions.explanation: GCWR stands for Gross Combination Weight Rating - the value specified by the manufacturer as the loaded weight of a combination vehicle.

questions.question: What does GVWR stand for?
questions.explanation: GVWR stands for Gross Vehicle Weight Rating - the value specified by the manufacturer as the loaded weight of a single vehicle.

questions.question: The air compressor governor cut-out is typically at what pressure?
questions.explanation: When air tank pressure rises to the 'cut-out' level (around 125 psi), the governor stops the compressor from pumping air.

questions.question: The air compressor governor cut-in is typically at what pressure?
questions.explanation: When the tank pressure falls to the 'cut-in' pressure (around 100 psi), the governor allows the compressor to start pumping again.

questions.question: At what pressure does the safety relief valve typically open?
questions.explanation: The safety valve is usually set to open at 150 psi to protect the tank and system from too much pressure.

questions.question: The low air pressure warning signal must come on before pressure drops below:
questions.explanation: A warning signal you can see must come on before the air pressure in the tanks falls below 55 psi.

questions.question: Spring brakes on trucks and tractors typically come fully on when air pressure drops to:
questions.explanation: Tractor and straight truck spring brakes will come fully on when air pressure drops to a range of 20 to 45 psi (typically 20 to 30 psi).

questions.question: What is the maximum air leakage rate for a single vehicle with the parking brake released?
questions.explanation: The loss rate should be less than two psi in one minute for single vehicles.

questions.question: What is the maximum air leakage rate for a combination vehicle with the parking brake released?
questions.explanation: The loss rate should be less than three psi in one minute for combination vehicles.

questions.question: What is the maximum air leakage rate for a single vehicle with the brake pedal applied?
questions.explanation: With the brake applied, air pressure should not drop more than three pounds in one minute for single vehicles.

questions.question: What is the maximum air leakage rate for a combination vehicle with the brake pedal applied?
questions.explanation: With the brake applied, air pressure should not drop more than four pounds in one minute for combination vehicles.

questions.question: Air brake lag distance at 55 mph adds approximately how many feet to stopping distance?
questions.explanation: The air brake lag distance at 55 mph on dry pavement adds about 32 feet.

questions.question: At 55 mph on dry pavement, the total stopping distance for a vehicle with air brakes is approximately:
questions.explanation: At 55 mph for an average driver under good traction and brake conditions, the total stopping distance is over 450 feet.

questions.question: What are the three braking systems in air brakes?
questions.explanation: Air brakes are really three different braking systems: service brake, parking brake, and emergency brake.

questions.question: Why must air tanks be drained?
choices: To remove water and oil that collects
questions.explanation: Compressed air usually has some water and compressor oil in it, which can cause brake failure (water can freeze in cold weather).

questions.question: If your vehicle does not have automatic air tank drains, when should you drain the tanks?
choices: At the end of each day of driving
questions.explanation: If your vehicle doesn't have automatic drains, drain your air tanks at the end of each working day.

questions.question: What is the most common type of foundation brake used on heavy vehicles?
questions.explanation: The most common type of foundation brake is the s-cam drum brake.

questions.question: What does ABS stand for?
questions.explanation: ABS stands for Antilock Braking System - a computerized system that keeps your wheels from locking up during hard brake applications.

questions.question: Truck tractors with air brakes built after what date are required to have ABS?
questions.explanation: Truck tractors with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1997 are required to be equipped with antilock brakes.

questions.question: Other air brake vehicles (trucks, buses, trailers, dollies) built after what date must have ABS?
questions.explanation: Other air brake vehicles built on or after March 1, 1998 are required to be equipped with antilock brakes.

questions.question: What color is the ABS malfunction lamp?
questions.explanation: Vehicles with ABS have yellow malfunction lamps to tell you if something isn't working.

questions.question: When air pressure builds from 85 to 100 psi in dual air systems, it should take no longer than:
questions.explanation: When the engine is at operating rpms, the pressure should build from 85 to 100 psi within 45 seconds in dual air systems.

questions.question: If a slack adjuster moves more than about how much when pulled, it probably needs adjustment?
questions.explanation: If a slack adjuster moves more than about one inch where the push rod attaches to it, it probably needs adjustment.

questions.question: What is the most common problem found in roadside inspections related to air brakes?
questions.explanation: Out-of-adjustment brakes are the most common problem found in roadside inspections.

questions.question: What should you do if the low air pressure warning comes on while driving?
choices: Pump the brakes to build pressure
Stop and safely park as soon as possible
questions.explanation: If the low air pressure warning comes on, stop and safely park your vehicle as soon as possible.

questions.question: What shape is the parking brake control knob on newer air brake vehicles?
questions.explanation: In newer vehicles with air brakes, you put on the parking brakes using a diamond-shaped, yellow, push-pull control knob.

questions.question: How long does air brake lag take (the time for brakes to work after pushing the pedal)?
questions.explanation: With air brakes, it takes a little time (one half second or more) for the air to flow through the lines to the brakes.

questions.question: A CDL with passenger endorsement is required when operating a vehicle designed to transport how many passengers (including the driver)?
questions.explanation: Bus drivers must have a CDL if they drive a vehicle designed to seat 16 or more persons, including the driver.

questions.question: What emergency equipment must a bus have?
choices: Fire extinguisher and emergency reflectors, plus spare fuses
questions.explanation: A bus must have a fire extinguisher and emergency reflectors (3 reflective triangles or at least 6 fusees or 3 liquid burning flares), plus spare electrical fuses unless equipped with circuit breakers.

questions.question: How many reflective triangles are required as emergency equipment?
questions.explanation: The bus must have 3 reflective triangles (or at least 6 fusees or 3 liquid burning flares).

questions.question: Where should standing passengers stay on a bus?
choices: In the front half of the bus
questions.explanation: No rider may stand forward of the rear of the driver's seat. All standing riders must stay behind the standee line.

questions.question: How wide is the standee line on a bus floor?
questions.explanation: Buses designed to allow standing must have a two-inch line on the floor showing riders where they cannot stand.

questions.question: What is the maximum total weight of hazardous materials that can be carried on a bus?
questions.explanation: Buses can carry no more than 500 pounds total of allowed hazardous materials.

questions.question: What is the maximum weight of any one class of hazardous material on a bus?
questions.explanation: No more than 100 pounds of any one class of hazardous material may be carried on a bus.

questions.question: How far from railroad crossings should a bus stop?
questions.explanation: Stop your bus between 15 and 50 feet before railroad crossings.

questions.question: At a drawbridge, how far back should you stop when there is no signal or attendant?
questions.explanation: Stop at least 50 feet before the draw of the bridge.

questions.question: What type of tires are prohibited on the front wheels of a bus?
questions.explanation: Front wheels must not have recapped or regrooved tires.

questions.question: Which hazardous materials can NEVER be carried on a bus?
choices: Division 2.3 poison gas and liquid Class 6 poison
questions.explanation: Buses must never carry Division 2.3 poison gas, liquid Class 6 poison, tear gas, or irritating materials.

questions.question: When are you NOT required to stop at a railroad crossing in a bus?
choices: When the traffic signal is green or a flagman directs you
When you can see no trains coming
questions.explanation: You do not have to stop, but must slow down and carefully check, when a traffic signal is green or a policeman/flagman is directing traffic.

questions.question: When crossing railroad tracks in a bus with a manual transmission, you should:
choices: Shift into a higher gear for speed
Stop on the tracks if traffic ahead stops
questions.explanation: If your bus has a manual transmission, never change gears while crossing the tracks.

questions.question: What should you do before allowing passengers to exit the bus?
choices: Wait for them to sit down or brace themselves
questions.explanation: Wait for passengers to sit down or brace themselves before starting. Starting and stopping should be smooth.

questions.question: Where should you discharge a disruptive passenger?
choices: At a safe location, not where it would be unsafe for them
questions.explanation: Don't discharge disruptive riders where it would be unsafe for them. It may be safer at the next scheduled stop or a well-lighted area where there are other people.

questions.question: Which of the following is a 'prohibited practice' for bus drivers?
choices: Fueling with passengers on board in a closed building
questions.explanation: Never refuel in a closed building with riders on board.

questions.question: When can you tow or push a disabled bus with passengers aboard?
choices: Only to the nearest safe spot to let passengers off
Only in emergencies approved by dispatch
questions.explanation: Do not tow or push a disabled bus with riders aboard unless getting off would be unsafe. Only tow or push to the nearest safe spot to discharge passengers.

questions.question: What is the brake-door interlock system?
choices: A lock that prevents door opening
A system that applies brakes and holds throttle at idle when rear door is open
An alarm when doors are open
questions.explanation: The brake-door interlock applies the brakes and holds the throttle in idle position when the rear door is open.

questions.question: Should you use the brake-door interlock in place of the parking brake?
choices: Yes, it's designed for that purpose
No, do not use it in place of the parking brake
Only when parked on level ground
questions.explanation: Do not use the brake-door interlock safety feature in place of the parking brake.

questions.question: What should you announce when arriving at a destination?
choices: Location, reason for stopping, next departure time, and bus number
questions.explanation: When arriving at the destination or intermediate stops, announce: the location, reason for stopping, next departure time, and bus number.

questions.question: The danger zone around a school bus can extend as much as how many feet from the front bumper?
questions.explanation: The danger zones may extend as much as 30 feet from the front bumper, with the first 10 feet being the most dangerous.

questions.question: The danger zone extends how many feet to the left and right sides of the bus?
questions.explanation: The danger zone extends 10 feet from the left and right sides of the bus.

questions.question: The danger zone extends how many feet behind the rear bumper?
questions.explanation: The danger zone extends 10 feet behind the rear bumper of the school bus.

questions.question: When approaching a school bus stop, you should activate alternating amber warning lights at least how many feet before the stop?
questions.explanation: Activate alternating flashing amber warning lights at least 200 feet or approximately 5-10 seconds before the school bus stop.

questions.question: When stopping to pick up students, the front bumper should be at least how far from students at the stop?
questions.explanation: Bring school bus to a full stop with the front bumper at least 10 feet away from students at the designated stop.

questions.question: After unloading, students should walk at least how far from the side of the bus?
questions.explanation: Tell students to exit the bus and walk at least 10 feet away from the side of the bus.

questions.question: How far should the outside flat mirrors let you see behind the bus?
questions.explanation: Ensure flat mirrors are adjusted so you can see 200 feet or 4 bus lengths behind the bus.

questions.question: What should students do if they drop something near the bus?
choices: Leave it and move to safety, then get driver's attention
Ask another student to get it
questions.explanation: Students should leave any dropped object and move to a point of safety out of the danger zones and attempt to get the driver's attention to retrieve the object.

questions.question: During mandatory evacuations, where should students be led to if there is a fire on the bus?
questions.explanation: Lead students upwind of the bus if fire is present.

questions.question: If there is a risk from hazardous materials during evacuation, students should be led at least how far away?
questions.explanation: Lead students upwind of the bus at least 300 feet if there is a risk from spilled hazardous materials.

questions.question: A safe place for evacuation should be at least how far off the road?
questions.explanation: A safe place will be at least 100 feet off the road in the direction of oncoming traffic.

questions.question: At a railroad crossing, how far from the nearest rail should a school bus stop?
questions.explanation: Stop no closer than 15 feet and no farther than 50 feet from the nearest rail.

questions.question: When crossing railroad tracks in a school bus, you should:
choices: Cross quickly in a high gear
Cross in a low gear and do not change gears while crossing
Stop in the middle to check for trains
Cross in neutral to save fuel
questions.explanation: Cross the tracks in a low gear. Do not change gears while crossing.

questions.question: If the gate comes down after you have started crossing the tracks, what should you do?
choices: Drive through the gate even if you break it
questions.explanation: If the gate comes down after you have started across, drive through it even if it means you will break the gate.

questions.question: What is a passive railroad crossing?
choices: A crossing without any traffic control device
questions.explanation: A passive crossing does not have any type of traffic control device - no flashing lights, bells, or gates.

questions.question: How much tail swing can a school bus have?
questions.explanation: A school bus can have up to a three-foot tail swing.

questions.question: When must you evacuate a school bus?
choices: When the bus is on fire or stalled on railroad tracks
Whenever you stop for more than 5 minutes
questions.explanation: You must evacuate when the bus is on fire or there is threat of fire, or when stalled on or adjacent to a railroad-highway crossing.

questions.question: Hydraulically braked school buses with a GVWR of 10,000 lbs or more must have ABS if built on or after:
questions.explanation: Hydraulically braked trucks and buses with a GVWR of 10,000 lbs or more built on or after March 1, 1999 are required to have ABS.

questions.question: If backing a school bus is unavoidable, when should students be picked up?
choices: Students should not be on the route if backing is needed
questions.explanation: If you must back-up at a student pick-up point, be sure to pick up students before backing.

questions.question: How far in front of the bus should students walk before crossing the roadway?
choices: 10 feet from the right front bumper
questions.explanation: Students should walk to a location at least 10 feet in front of the right corner of the bumper, but still remaining away from the front of the school bus.
